conclusion: The vertical axis shows velocity (v) in m/s^-1 and the horizontal axis shows time (t) in seconds. The graph shows the skydiver's vertical velocity over time.

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time: a = dv/dt. On a v-t graph, acceleration corresponds to the slope of the curve at any point: Positive slope → positive acceleration, Negative slope → negative acceleration, Zero slope → zero acceleration.
At t = 0, velocity is 0 m/s. The velocity increases in a curved manner. At t = 10, velocity reaches approximately 20 m/s.

premise: The slope of the curve during the 0-10 seconds interval is always positive, but gradually decreases.
conclusion: The acceleration is positive during the 0-10 seconds interval.
Positive velocity means downward motion (falling). The skydiver starts from rest (v = 0 at t = 0). Velocity increases in the downward direction.
For vertical motion near Earth's surface, acceleration due to gravity points downward. Drag force from air resistance points in the opposite direction of motion (upward in this case).

premise: Since the slope of the v-t graph is positive throughout the 0-10 second interval, the acceleration is positive.
conclusion: In this context, positive acceleration means the acceleration is in the downward direction (same as the velocity).

premise: The curved shape of the line (decreasing slope) indicates that the magnitude of the acceleration is decreasing over time.
conclusion: This is consistent with air resistance gradually increasing as velocity increases, partially counteracting gravity.

premise: During the 0-10 seconds interval, the acceleration is in the downward direction (positive in this coordinate system).
conclusion: Therefore, the acceleration direction is downward from 0 to 10 seconds.
